topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Ada frames the fear of feeling trapped late-career and the importance of aligning work with values. Lenny introduces Ada’s background (Notejoy co-founder, executive coach, ex-SurveyMonkey/LinkedIn) and previews key topics.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates library
topics.summary: Sponsor read describing Sprig’s in-app user insights tooling and new templates library, including Lenny’s product sense playbook.

topics.title: Curiosity Loops: structured advice gathering
topics.summary: Ada explains her “Curiosity Loop” method: ask a well-formed, specific, unbiased question; choose the right people; make it easy to respond; then synthesize and close the loop with thanks. They discuss why this beats generic advice and how it reduces cognitive load for respondents.

topics.title: Curiosity Loops in personal life decisions
topics.summary: Ada shares using curiosity loops beyond work, including estate planning decisions about when a child should inherit assets. They discuss how informal repeated questioning surfaces better defaults and unexpected research (e.g., executive function development).

topics.title: Topic selection feedback and “no winning” topics
topics.summary: They review feedback from Ada’s curiosity loop about which podcast topics to avoid, including hiring/onboarding and the risks of discussing being a woman in Silicon Valley. Lenny jokes about covering the “avoid” topic anyway.

topics.title: Values exercise: building an internal scorecard
topics.summary: Ada describes a lightweight values-identification exercise used in her coaching to clarify what matters internally versus external status metrics. Lenny shares his values list (adventure, optimism, kindness, improvement, generosity, and a grandma rule).

topics.title: Applying values to Lenny’s “say yes/no” dilemma
topics.summary: They apply Lenny’s values to choosing commitments (podcast, book, angel investing) and the desire to simplify ahead of having a child. Ada helps unpack how “adventure” can fade into treadmill work over time.

topics.title: Early career strategy: explore vs exploit
topics.summary: Ada outlines her rapid career progression using an “explore then exploit” approach: early experimentation across roles/companies with hypotheses, then deliberate skill-building for founder readiness. She walks through Microsoft → startup → founding Connected → LinkedIn growth/subscriptions → SurveyMonkey SVP marketing.

topics.title: When to stick it out vs leave a job
topics.summary: Ada shares heuristics for deciding whether to stay: watch for inertia and “boiling frog” drift, and evaluate whether you’re still learning and growing. She suggests proactive manager conversations, reshaping projects, or using “gift of time” to learn/build relationships if growth is blocked.

topics.title: Resume optimization vs meaningful work alignment
topics.summary: They discuss the trap of optimizing for logos/titles and realizing your resume is your life. Ada connects this to values alignment and avoiding late-career regret driven by lifestyle expectations or others’ approval.

topics.title: Sponsor Break: Sprig templates (repeat)
topics.summary: Second sponsor read reiterating Sprig’s templates library and Lenny’s product sense playbook.

topics.title: Trigger for reevaluating career: values vs prestige
topics.summary: Ada describes a pivotal high-profile opportunity that looked great externally but conflicted with her top values (travel, hours, lack of excitement). They discuss the “ego monster” and Warren Buffett’s inner vs outer scorecard framing.

topics.title: Coaching: who needs it and alternatives
topics.summary: Ada offers a contrarian take that most people don’t need a coach and should clarify goals first. She suggests alternatives like curiosity loops, mentors, courses (e.g., Reforge), and building community support before paying for coaching.
